stories.headline: Alcatraz proposal called 'not serious'
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has ordered federal agencies to reopen Alcatraz prison as a functioning prison 62 years after its closure. The plan faces criticism as impractical due to the prison's small capacity, deteriorating conditions, and high operational costs. Experts and politicians say reopening the cellblock is 'absurd,' 'infeasible,' and 'far-fetched' because the building is decaying and lacks essential facilities. The prison was originally closed due to its vulnerability to escape attempts and cost inefficiency.

stories.headline: Garden a space to recall lives lost to cancer
stories.summary: Vanessa Onsurez of Santa Cruz was in pain from metastatic breast cancer but attended the opening of the Bay Area Young Survivors Breast Cancer Memorial Garden, a $1 million monument dedicated to people who died from breast cancer, especially those under 45. Onsurez felt supported by this community space, which features 200 hearts crocheted to raise awareness. The garden serves as a place for reflection and remembrance for survivors and families.

stories.headline: Another sequel for decrepit theater
stories.summary: San Francisco's Richmond District has a deteriorating Alexandria Theater that has been vacant for over two decades. Developers have tried and failed to redevelop the site due to political pressure. A new proposal aims to turn the theater into residential and commercial space with 75 housing units, some affordable, while preserving the historic facade and interior details. The city supervisors are considering creating a special district to facilitate the redevelopment.

stories.headline: Consumers stocked up amid tariff fears
stories.summary: Foot traffic at U.S. warehouse stores surged in the weeks before tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump, particularly during the first week of April when reciprocal tariffs were set to take effect. Data from Placer.ai indicated a significant increase in shopper visits to warehouse, superstore, grocery, and gas stations as consumers aimed to beat rising prices. A survey by NielsenIQ of 1,000 consumers showed that 31% stocked up on groceries anticipating tariff impacts, while others rushed nonperishable purchases before price hikes took hold.

stories.headline: Americans closer to living on streets than like Musk
stories.summary: An analytical piece discusses the growing issue of homelessness in America, highlighting that more individuals are nearing the struggle of living on the streets than achieving the wealth exemplified by figures like Elon Musk. The coverage explores socioeconomic challenges and disparity with an emphasis on the widening gap between extreme poverty and extreme wealth in the country.

stories.headline: Flower workshops coming up
stories.summary: Jenny Creek Flowers in the Finger Lakes region has announced a series of flower workshops for the summer 2025 season. Located in Trumansburg, the flower farm will offer multiple hands-on workshops where customers can pick flowers and create their own bouquets. Farmer Brooke Palmer emphasizes that the event promotes relaxation and enjoying the beauty of the season, alongside providing simple flower arranging tips. A notable upcoming workshop is the Peony Grow & Design Workshop scheduled for June 7 in Ithaca, designed to foster floral creativity.

stories.headline: World Atlas names 11 serene getaway spots in NY
stories.summary: The World Atlas has identified 11 towns in New York as serene getaway spots, offering quiet retreats away from the busy city life of Manhattan. One highlighted destination is Lake Placid, located in the Adirondacks, known for its winter olympics history and outdoor activities such as skiing and hiking. Another spot mentioned is Crown Point in Essex County, situated on the western shore of Lake Champlain. These towns provide scenic views and a peaceful environment for weekend retreats, appealing to those seeking tranquility amidst nature.

stories.headline: States sue over health agency
stories.summary: New York Attorney General Letitia James and 18 other Democratic state attorneys general have filed a federal lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. The suit challenges the Trump administration's efforts to overhaul the department by cutting its size and laying off 20,000 employees, which is seen as putting countless lives at risk by undermining public health progress.

stories.headline: Glendale shooting leaves 3 dead, 5 hurt
stories.summary: A fight during a crowded dance party at a mariscos and steak restaurant in Glendale escalated into a gun battle, resulting in three deaths and five injuries. The three who died were brothers aged 17, 21, and 21. The shooting was reportedly caused by 'bad blood' between individuals. Police investigated the scene and confirmed the incident was a targeted altercation.

stories.headline: Nine-story waterslide debuts
stories.summary: A new waterslide at Golfland Sunsplash in Mesa has opened, featuring a towering height of 9 stories. It is now the tallest waterslide in Arizona and offers a new attraction for waterpark visitors.

stories.headline: Hobbs nixes transparency bill
stories.summary: Governor Katie Hobbs vetoed a bill that aimed to provide transparency about political donors who seek state contracts and grants. This decision has sparked discussion regarding political transparency in the state.

stories.headline: Remark made at ballpark talks felt like veiled threat
stories.summary: Negotiations involving tax-payer dollars for Chase Field repairs have raised concerns after a comment made at a recent private meeting was perceived as a veiled threat. The meeting, involving representatives of the Diamondbacks, lawmakers, and officials, stalled the passage of a funding bill, impacting the legislative process.

stories.headline: Israel plans to seize Gaza, officials say
stories.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu described intensified operations in Gaza involving plans for indefinite control and mass relocations of Palestinians. The strategy involves securing the enclave with large military forces to root out Hamas fighters and destroy tunnels. A cabinet-approved plan may require tens of thousands of reservists, aiming to control northern and southern Gaza and establish secured zones controlled by Israeli Defense Forces.

stories.headline: Selfridge jet plan not yet cleared for takeoff
stories.summary: Despite promises from President Donald Trump to replace the A-10 squadron at Selfridge Air National Guard Base with F-15EX fighter jets, key steps still need to be finalized. The project involves approximately $2 billion in funding and multiple environmental and construction phases. Funding and studies are ongoing, but the base's runway needs realignment, with officials expressing cautious optimism about the timeline for this change.

stories.headline: Detroit envisions new life for old substations
stories.summary: Detroit is looking to repurpose 10 former Detroit Public Lighting Commission substations scattered throughout the city. These old buildings, examples of early 20th-century industrial architecture, are being put up for sale and pitched as architectural jewels for developers. Officials hope to turn them into diverse commercial and industrial spaces, including lofts and restaurants, with many already sold or under development.

stories.headline: The insult that cost UM its president
stories.summary: Just six months ago, University of Michigan President Santa Ono signed a contract extension to stay for at least another seven years. However, news broke that Ono will become the new leader of the University of Florida. The situation highlights internal conflicts and board meddling related to Michigan regents wanting to cut Ono's pay despite his contract. Democrats on the board pressured Ono amid political controversies involving federal policies and antisemitism.

stories.headline: Ford reports 64% 1Q income drop; automakers brace for tariff impacts
stories.summary: Ford Motor Company reported a significant 64% drop in income in the first quarter, raising concerns about tariff impacts on the automotive industry. Automakers are bracing for the economic effects of ongoing and potential trade tariffs that may affect profits and production costs moving forward.

stories.headline: A Budding Controversy?
stories.summary: Chris Yamamoto has been battling Barrington Hills officials for over a year concerning zoning codes as he attempts to reopen his flower farm. Despite these challenges, his passion for the project remains strong.

stories.headline: Schakowsky Won't Seek Reelection to U.S. House Seat She's Held Since '99
stories.summary: U.S. Representative Schakowsky has announced she will not seek reelection for the House seat she has held since 1999, marking the end of a long political career.

stories.headline: UF finalist to visit campus
stories.summary: The University of Florida will get an up-close look at the only candidate for its open presidency Tuesday when Santa Ono, president at the University of Michigan, visits Gainesville for a series of meetings with students, faculty and staff. Ono, Michigan's president since 2022, will outline his vision for Florida's flagship university and its student body of more than 60,000. His visit promises to be quieter after past controversies Ono faced regarding diversity and protests during his tenure at previous institutions.

stories.headline: Florida sued over constitutional amendment petition law
stories.summary: Governor Ron DeSantis signed a law changing the process for creating ballot initiatives in Florida. The law affects how medical aid is requested and requires collecting nearly 900,000 petition signatures from Florida citizens. The group Florida Decides Healthcare is suing, arguing the law imposes vague and excessive requirements that violate First Amendment protections for free speech. The dispute centers on concerns about fraud and abuse in the ballot initiative system.

stories.headline: Ex-prosecutor claims self-defense in stabbing
stories.summary: Patrick Scruggs, a former prosecutor, claims self-defense after stabbing another driver during a traffic crash on the Howard Frankland Bridge in 2023. Scruggs appeared enraged and witnesses testified about the incident where Scruggs slammed the man's window and stabbed him multiple times with a knife. The situation escalated after an argument in traffic, and Scruggs says he acted in panic and for his safety. The case is under judicial consideration for a possible stand your ground trial.

stories.headline: Partner deported; mom, kids stuck in legal limbo
stories.summary: Angela Leal and her two daughters are stuck in a difficult legal situation after her boyfriend was deported in 2023. Without passports, her daughters cannot return to Chile. Leal's boyfriend was arrested during an immigration appointment and deported to El Salvador, creating uncertainty and fear for the family. The Chilean consulate and authorities are involved, but the process of securing passports and legal status for minors remains unresolved.

stories.headline: Voting proposal requiring proof of citizenship dies
stories.summary: A Michigan House Republican proposal to amend the state constitution to require new voter registrants to show proof of U.S. citizenship was defeated in the House for lacking the needed two-thirds majority. While 58 Republicans voted in favor and all 48 Democrats opposed, the measure likely would have failed in the Senate as well. The proposal aimed to require documentation for voter registration, reject votes without ID, and have the secretary of state verify citizenship for all voters.

stories.headline: Tense town halls have lawmakers rethinking communications
stories.summary: Michigan lawmakers are reconsidering how they communicate with their constituents after tense town halls and insufficient responses from members of Congress. The Grand Rapids Press surveyed the U.S. House of Representatives' Michigan delegation, revealing variations in communication channels and responsiveness. Issues include a shift to virtual meetings, the use of social media by some members, and frustration among Republicans and Democrats with constituent interactions under President Donald Trump's administration.

stories.headline: In the crosshairs of Canadian vacation plans
stories.summary: Michigan faces challenges in its tourism sector as fewer Canadian visitors are crossing the border this year compared to previous years. Border cities that rely heavily on Canadian tourists, including shoppers and vacationers, may experience economic impacts from this decline. Travel data indicate a downturn in visits through major entry points at airports and ports of entry, affecting Michigan's $400 million tourism economy that largely benefits from Canadian arrivals.

stories.headline: People could get $1,000 to deport on their own
stories.summary: The Department of Homeland Security announced that immigrants illegally in the U.S. could receive $1,000 and travel assistance for voluntarily deporting themselves using an app called CBP Home. The program aims to provide a cost effective and safe option for self-deportation with some tickets already booked to Honduras.

stories.headline: Chattanoogans present agenda to city officials for bettering city
stories.summary: A group of Chattanoogans worked with Mayor Tim Kelly to propose an agenda aimed at improving the city through sustainable development and cultural enrichment as part of the newly granted National Park City designation. The approach encourages local residents to contribute ideas and collaborative efforts without creating a new organization.

stories.headline: 'Ethics Bowl' lets students discuss, not debate topics
stories.summary: In the National Speech and Debate Tournament, high school students engage in the 'Ethics Bowl' where rather than debating, teams discuss ethical issues respectfully by defending and opposing assigned positions without attacking individuals. This approach encourages critical thinking and understanding of differing viewpoints.

stories.headline: Tackling the Deficit
stories.summary: Hamilton County Schools faces an $18.5 million budget deficit prompting officials to propose cuts including job reductions and altering magnet busing to manage lower-than-expected revenues and rising costs, particularly a $12.5 million increase in healthcare. The district presented the budget proposal which requires approval from the Hamilton County Commission.

stories.headline: New state law aims to boost the reporting of child abuse
stories.summary: Governor Mike Braun signed a new law aimed at improving the reporting of child abuse in Indiana. The legislation requires law enforcement to investigate allegations of abuse or neglect involving school staff or volunteers and delegates reporting duties accordingly. Introduced by Rep. Becky Cash, the law draws inspiration from a 2016 IndyStar investigation and seeks to enhance child protection measures statewide.

stories.headline: ‘It is very hard to hold officers accountable’
stories.summary: Elkhart is still facing challenges in dealing with police misconduct, as highlighted by the case of former patrol officer Steve Ambrose, who was disciplined multiple times but was rarely held accountable by the local police department during the 1980s and 1990s. The investigation reveals a culture of overlooking allegations, resolving claims quietly with settlements, and lacking proper disciplinary action, reflecting ongoing struggles in police accountability in Indiana.

stories.headline: Legislative oversight in focus for IN this session
stories.summary: The Indiana legislature, dominated by Republicans, has focused this session on increasing oversight of state officials by banning no-bid contracts and restricting luxury purchases with tax dollars. Senate Enrolled Act 5 mandates that contracts be made public within 30 days, a move aimed at responding to concerns from constituents about state government transparency and ethics regarding GOP state officeholders.

stories.headline: Woman charged in crosswalk attacks
stories.summary: Sophia Elizabeth Sullivan was charged with multiple criminal counts including murder and assault after deliberately running over pedestrians in two back-to-back crashes in Minneapolis that left one pedestrian dead and three others hurt. Authorities have not released the victims' identities and the motive remains unclear, while investigators await further updates on other recent homicides in Minneapolis.

stories.headline: Blue Cross to pay out $71M to settle suit
stories.summary: Health insurer Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Minnesota plans to pay $71 million as part of a nationwide settlement for stifling competition and causing economic harm to health care providers. The settlement is part of a broader $2.8 billion fund to resolve damage claims and includes changes to health plan operations and provider networks to enhance affordability and competition.

stories.headline: Court says toplessness not lewd act
stories.summary: Police officers charged a woman for allegedly exposing her breasts in a parking lot, but the court ruled that toplessness is not necessarily illegal and is not automatically considered a lewd act. The case highlights questions about legal protections around exposure in public and was determined not to be a criminal offense in this context.

stories.headline: Israel plans to seize Gaza Strip
stories.summary: Israel approved plans to seize the Gaza Strip and move tens of thousands of Palestinians to the south of the enclave, vastly expanding military operations and potentially worsening the humanitarian crisis. The plan awaits further implementation details and faces international opposition, with ongoing negotiations and military actions continuing in the region.

stories.headline: Hoping to solve crisis of mentally ill people stuck in hospitals, jail
stories.summary: A legislative effort aims to address the challenges faced by mentally ill individuals who remain stuck in hospitals, jail, and other facilities due to lack of timely access to mental health care services. Advocates stress the importance of a mental health system with transformational reforms and expanded programs to improve outcomes and reduce the burden on hospitals and correctional facilities.

stories.headline: Council interviews three candidates for city manager
stories.summary: Kansas City Mayor Lucas will soon announce who he wants to serve as city manager for the remaining two years and three months he has left before term limits end his stay at City Hall. It will then be up to the rest of the City Council to either ratify that nominee, or start the process all over again. A redo is not likely, as Lucas is a seasoned politician who knows how to count votes before sticking his neck out. The person he nominates is almost certain to get the support he or she needs to take on the most important job in city government. And that person will most certainly hold onto it at least for the remainder of this council term, absent unforeseen circumstances.

stories.headline: Northland residents respond to hate speech signs with love, unity
stories.summary: In Kansas City’s Northland, residents woke up to racist and antisemitic flyers posted throughout the Shoal Creek neighborhood. Neighbors reportedly acted swiftly to remove the flyers and expressed shock and surprise at their presence. Parents in North Brook and surrounding neighborhoods responded by posting their own anti-hate flyers and sharing heartfelt messages to promote unity and reject hate, emphasizing that their community is welcoming and diverse.

stories.headline: Bus driver shortage hurts child care access in Spring Hill
stories.summary: An ongoing bus driver shortage in Kansas City is limiting families' child care options in at least one district in the metro area. For the first time in 21 years of operation, Day Brook Learning Center in Spring Hill will not offer its afterschool care program. A recent change means only two out of five elementary schools in Spring Hill will bus students to Day Brook, limiting the center's clientele and forcing fewer kids to attend, according to the center’s owner and director, Dana Broeckerd.

stories.headline: ‘A WALKING ANGEL’ Loved ones, officials remember slain paramedic at funeral
stories.summary: The funeral for slain Kansas City firefighter-paramedic Graham Hoffman attracted dozens of firefighters and first responders from local agencies far and wide, including from California. The ceremony included bible verses embodying care and duty and many attendees expressed grief through hugs, handshakes, and tears. Hoffman's casket was draped with an American flag and carried onto the fire truck as a tribute. He was fatally stabbed during treatment of a patient inside an ambulance, leading to a large public visitation and a heartfelt farewell.

stories.headline: Courier wins first round in lottery lawsuit
stories.summary: A lottery courier company sued the Texas Lottery Commission over a new rule that threatened their business by potentially revoking retail licenses for lottery retailers using courier services. A State District Judge issued a temporary restraining order against enforcement of the rule, preventing actions against the courier company. The ruling casts doubt on the commission's enforcement power, drawing criticism from lawmakers. Meanwhile, legislation to abolish the lottery was also discussed but no vote was taken.

stories.headline: Border counties reckoning with their support of Trump
stories.summary: Border counties in Texas that overwhelmingly supported President Donald Trump in the past elections now face challenges due to his threatened tariffs, attacks on social programs, and immigration crackdown. While some voters remain confident in Trump, others are worried about border security and economic realities affecting the border cities. This shift in political outlook highlights the complex dynamics at play in these historically Democratic and Hispanic regions, particularly as Trump's approval rating faces headwinds.

stories.headline: Paxton going after Austin schools
stories.summary: Attorney General Ken Paxton announced legal action against the Austin school district, investigating whether there is an unwritten policy related to critical race theory (CRT). This follows a Texas Legislature ban on CRT in public education. The investigation stems from claims that the Austin ISD uses curricula linked to the 1619 Project and promotes concepts deemed as CRT. The goal is to begin the legal process to depose the Superintendent and Board Trustees of Austin ISD. Paxton's office has gathered evidence but specifics remain unclear, with the district denying indoctrination claims and declining comment.

stories.headline: Diddy jury selection could be drawn out
stories.summary: Sean "Diddy" Combs faces a trial on sexual assault charges. Jury selection involves questioning over celebrities and sexual abuse, and could be lengthy. Combs has traded his fashion for navy and white attire for court appearances. Jurors, questioned by the judge, prosecution, and defense, must remain unbiased in this high-profile case. Question topics include sexual assault and familiarity with notable figures like Destiny's Child's Michelle Williams and comedian Mike Myers. The trial details remain unfolding.

stories.headline: Job cuts complicate hopes for coal revival
stories.summary: Robert Cash, a coal miner in West Virginia, and his fellow miners hope to keep giving up coal to pay rare six-figure salaries but fear layoffs and safety risks. While fatal accidents have decreased, black lung disease cases have risen. President Donald Trump's promises to revive the coal industry are challenged by federal cost-cutting and weakening mine safety. The federal workforce cuts to the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) and delayed regulations add risks to coal miners' health and safety.

stories.headline: Trump's idea for reopening Alcatraz was tried before
stories.summary: President Donald Trump suggested reopening Alcatraz Island as a prison, a concept previously used in movies like "The Rock" and "Escape From Alcatraz." The island prison, closed for over 60 years, featured in popular films and was known for its notoriety. Trump's mention of "REBUILD, AND OPEN ALCATRAZ" on social media sparked interest, yet this is not the first time such reopening has been proposed. The island remains a symbol with a storied past and cultural significance.

stories.headline: Jockeying for pope begins before conclave
stories.summary: With the passing of Pope Francis, hundreds of cardinals are gathering in Rome to elect a successor. Discussions about who will lead the nearly 2,000-year-old Catholic Church have already begun, even though the conclave has not yet started. Pope Francis, the first American head of the Catholic Church, left a significant legacy. Around 250 cardinals have been summoned to Italy for business and the pope's funeral, highlighting the intrigue around the next papal election.

stories.headline: Buffett wants DM man as his successor
stories.summary: Warren Buffett, the legendary investor and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, announced his intention to step down and wants Greg Abel, a Des Moines resident and vice chairman, to succeed him as CEO by the end of the year. Buffett highlighted Abel's qualifications and pledged to inform the board officially. He also stated he has no plans to sell any Berkshire stock and will remain involved to some extent following the transition.

stories.headline: New downtown federal courthouse set to open by June
stories.summary: A federal court filing has indicated that the new downtown federal courthouse in Des Moines will open by June 16, earlier than the initially scheduled July date. The $136 million, 229,000-square-foot building has faced delays and legal challenges but will replace the existing 97,470-square-foot federal courthouse. The courthouse is situated near 123 E. Walnut St. and features modern facilities to accommodate federal court needs.

stories.headline: HOME-FEEL ADVANTAGE
stories.summary: Caitlin Clark returned to Carver-Hawkeye Arena to play with the Indiana Fever against the Brazil national team in front of a packed crowd. The Fever won the game 108-44. Clark's return drew an enthusiastic audience, highlighting her popular connection to Iowa and the arena where she first gained basketball recognition.

stories.headline: Electric school bus maker Lion faces likely liquidation
stories.summary: Lion Electric opened its sprawling 900,000-square-foot plant near Joliet in 2023, touting the potential for 1,400 new jobs. However, the Quebec-based electric school bus maker has faced setbacks, including a court-appointed monitor's warning of a likely liquidation. Despite initial optimism about federal grants, pollution reduction, and clean commuter rides, Lion struggled to expand in the United States. Prominent Illinois officials, including Gov. JB Pritzker, have expressed commitment to maintaining an EV ecosystem, while Rivian continues investment in a nearby supplier park to support production growth.

stories.headline: As aquifer dries up, some Will County towns say they aren’t worried about losing water
stories.summary: Towns in Will County near Chicago face challenges as their regional water source, an underground aquifer, nears depletion by 2030. Despite studies warning many suburbs will run out of water supplied by the Cambrian-Ordovician aquifer, some local officials remain unconcerned about water loss, aiming to find alternatives. The Illinois State Water Survey and the Prairie Water Commission are engaged in addressing future water needs and building infrastructure such as a pumping station in Joliet to manage the crisis.

stories.headline: US Rep. Schakowsky announces she will not seek another term
stories.summary: U.S. Rep. Jan Schakowsky announced she will not seek another term after representing a Far North Side and northwest suburban district since 1999. At 80 years old, Schakowsky cited a desire not to run again for Congress and the end of an era in a reliably Democratic district. Her retirement announcement follows a history of political maneuvers and endorsements within the district, which includes Evanston and suburbs. Key local political figures have noted the significance of her decision as new candidates consider the upcoming open seat.

stories.headline: Steppenwolf Theatre play 'Purpose' wins Pulitzer
stories.summary: 'Purpose,' a play by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins commissioned by Chicago's Steppenwolf Theatre Company, won the 2025 Pulitzer Prize for drama. Debuting in Chicago in 2024 and loosely based on the family of civil rights leader Jesse Jackson, the play has garnered acclaim for its ensemble-driven work and social themes. The award highlights Steppenwolf's continued prominence in the arts and its commitment to impactful storytelling. The Pulitzer board also recognized other categories including journalism and poetry with winners from Columbia University events.

stories.headline: Trump in Palm Beach
stories.summary: President Donald Trump arrived at Palm Beach International Airport on May 1 and spent the weekend at his Mar-a-Lago residence. An AI-generated image of Trump as the pope, a proposal to reopen Alcatraz prison, and calls for movie tariffs marked the latest visit, drawing rebuke from New York bishops. Cardinals worldwide are preparing for a conclave to elect a new pope, and Trump’s social media post drew criticism from Catholic leaders.
people: Catholic Bishops of New York State

stories.headline: Suspect alarmed his fellow students
stories.summary: Investigators who flagged Damian Allen's violent online messages were not the first to notice his obsession with school shooters. Four years earlier, a police officer and a 15-year-old student at Forest Hill High School reported concerning 'Columbine comments' made by Allen. The student felt 'incredibly uncomfortable,' and Allen's behavior, including groping the girl and threatening comments, were reported to authorities. The suspect is charged in connection with the 2022 West Palm Beach school attack.

stories.headline: McLaren’s Piastri and Norris finish 1-2 at Miami Grand Prix
stories.summary: In a remarkable sports performance, McLaren teammates Piastri and Norris finished first and second respectively at the Miami Grand Prix, showcasing strong teamwork and driving skills. This result significantly boosts McLaren’s standing in the racing season and excites fans about the team’s prospects.

stories.headline: Florida AG challenging immigration ruling
stories.summary: Florida Attorney General James Uthmeier is contesting a federal judge’s order blocking parts of Florida’s immigration law. The order by U.S. District Judge Kathleen Williams halts enforcement of parts of the law that criminalize undocumented immigrants entering or re-entering Florida. The AG vows to vigorously defend state laws and advance President Trump’s agenda on illegal immigration. The Attorney General’s office has appealed the ruling after a federal court decision cited federal supremacy and interference issues.

stories.headline: 7 PBC educators receive honors
stories.summary: Seven educators in the Palm Beach County School District received the Dwyer Award for Excellence in Education on May 5. The awards, sponsored by the Economic Council of Palm Beach County, recognize leadership and contributions in various subject areas. Winners received $3,500 with finalists earning $500, honoring William T. Dwyer, a former Pratt & Whitney vice president. The recipients excelled in education and demonstrated commitment to student progress and support.

stories.headline: Post wins Pulitzers for breaking news, cartoons
stories.summary: The Washington Post received top honors for its reporting on the assassination attempt on Donald Trump and notable cartoons. The award highlights the newsroom's dedication to covering critical national events with impactful journalism and photography.

stories.headline: OpenAI scraps plan to become for-profit firm
stories.summary: OpenAI's nonprofit board has decided against transitioning to a for-profit corporation amidst criticism from Elon Musk, who had sued to block the restructuring. The move preserves OpenAI's mission to ensure AI benefits humanity fully, continuing with mixed funding sources including partnerships and investments in AI technology.

stories.headline: A contracting economy squeezes U.S. housing
stories.summary: The U.S. housing market is experiencing increased costs due to tariffs, leading to higher prices for building materials and mortgages. Analysts note a slowdown in home sales and remodeling activities amid broader economic challenges including rising interest and mortgage rates, signaling a tighter market environment ahead.

stories.headline: Texas poised to increase control over universities
stories.summary: Texas is considering a bill that could significantly impact academic freedom by giving the state power to screen faculty and potentially control university governance. This controversial measure is advancing through the legislature and has raised concerns about its effects on higher education statewide.

stories.headline: Israel to seize parts of Gaza
stories.summary: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced an intensified operation in Gaza involving a large-scale relocation of the Palestinian population and indefinite Israeli military control over key areas. This plan includes establishing aid hubs and calling upon reservists amid ongoing conflict with Hamas. The move aims to strategically cut off Hamas access and manage the territory long-term but raises significant humanitarian concerns.

stories.headline: NFL draft could draw 1M to D.C., leaders say
stories.summary: NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell, Washington Commanders owner Josh Harris, and D.C. Mayor Muriel E. Bowser gathered to announce that the NFL draft will be held in D.C. in spring 2027, potentially attracting over a million people to the National Mall and boosting the city's pro football franchise resurgence. This event marks a significant moment endorsed by key leaders, including former President Donald Trump.

stories.headline: OpenAI Abandons Its Plan To Convert Into a For-Profit
stories.summary: OpenAI abandoned its controversial plan to place its artificial intelligence business under control of a for-profit entity. The company's future funding decisions may affect the nonprofit board's control and its long-term direction after delays and internal disagreements.

stories.headline: China’s Official Statistics Are Disappearing
stories.summary: Chinese authorities have increasingly withheld official economic data, complicating efforts to assess the nation's economic health. Missing information on key indicators such as land sales, consumer spending, and business confidence casts doubts on the accuracy of China's reported economic performance.

stories.headline: Tariff Plot Twist Panics Hollywood
stories.summary: Hollywood actors and producers have argued with politicians over tariffs on imported movies and TV productions, which may cause higher costs and threaten industry stability. The administration's call for tariffs on social media platforms also raised concerns within the entertainment sector.

stories.headline: Trump Threatens Colleges If Student Loans Not Repaid
stories.summary: The Trump administration threatened to enforce student loan repayments by colleges and universities, warning that students may need to repay loans outright. The stance comes amidst concerns about an increasing amount of outstanding student debt and the ongoing debate about federal aid and loan forgiveness.

stories.headline: Israel To Hold Big Parts Of Gaza, Run Aid
stories.summary: Israel's security cabinet approved a ground operation to occupy parts of the Gaza Strip, aiming to clear territory of Hamas militants and control aid distribution. Prime Minister Netanyahu emphasized the strategic significance but assured international observers about the efforts to provide humanitarian assistance amid the conflict.

stories.headline: Fashion Spends a Gala Night at the Museum
stories.summary: Actress Lupita Nyong'o arrived at the Met Gala in a pastel green suit and sweeping cape, showcasing the event's theme 'Superfine: Tailoring Black Style' at the Metropolitan Museum in New York City. The gala celebrated fashion's annual fete with elegance and style.

stories.headline: Trump offers $1,000 to immigrants who go back home voluntarily
stories.summary: The Trump administration announced it would offer $1,000 and a free flight home to undocumented immigrants who voluntarily return to their home countries, using the CBP Home App to facilitate lawful entry appointments and payments, aiming to reduce costs of deportation and manage immigration enforcement.

stories.headline: Jury selection begins in Diddy’s sex trafficking trial in New York
stories.summary: Jury selection for Sean 'Diddy' Combs' federal sex trafficking trial started in New York, with the defendant facing multiple charges including racketeering and transportation to engage in prostitution, while a small group of media and onlookers gathered outside the Manhattan courthouse.

stories.headline: People over profits came with steep price for owner of Allapattah arts space
stories.summary: Fabian Martinez, founder of Esquina de Abuela, faces eviction from his cultural institution in Allapattah after years of community service and underground arts events, highlighting the challenges of running a mission-driven business in Miami's competitive real estate market as property values surge and legal battles have taken a toll.

stories.headline: Feeling squeezed? Your apartment in Miami is getting smaller, survey says
stories.summary: Miami apartments have shrunk to below 900 square feet on average for the first time in at least a decade, as new developments focus on studios and one-bedroom units amid rising demand for smaller living spaces, with median rents in South Florida also increasing according to real estate data.

stories.headline: New horse in the race?
stories.summary: The owners of an RV and equestrian park near Santa Fe Regional Airport propose a redevelopment plan to add an amphitheater with seating capacity between 3,500 to 5,500, aiming to enhance and expand the site's offerings. The once-thriving horse park, HIPICO, had struggled with popularity during the pandemic, but the new proposal hopes to transform the site into an entertainment and outdoor recreation destination.

stories.headline: Netanyahu warns of escalation in Gaza campaign
stories.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared increasing military action against Gaza, citing the intensified offensive as necessary to conclude current hostilities and bring back hostages. Netanyahu warned of an intensive escalation over an 18-month war, with increased military efforts to end the situation after months of blockade and bombardment of the Gaza Strip. The escalation follows a security cabinet approval for expanded operations in the embattled areas.

stories.headline: Conspiracy charges after Dec. shooting
stories.summary: Three individuals face felony charges after police allege a 42-year-old man fired a shot near his son's home and subsequently fabricated a burglary story with his son and daughter-in-law. Among those charged is Joseph Padilla, 49, with aggravated battery involving a deadly weapon and conspiracy to commit aggravated battery. Padilla's son, Joshua Padilla, 27, and daughter-in-law, Ashley Morrison, 32, are also accused in connection with the incident. The Santa Fe County Sheriff's Office has moved forward with charges after reviewing the complaint filed in Santa Fe County Magistrate Court.

stories.headline: Ex-SFPS chief to sue school board over investigation
stories.summary: Hilario "Larry" Chavez, who stepped down as Santa Fe Public Schools superintendent amid accusations of sexual harassment, plans to sue the school board due to what he claims is a mishandled investigation prompting his resignation. Chavez had spent nearly four years as superintendent of athletics and activities and school support, and after his resignation, the school board authorized attorneys to proceed with an investigation into allegations made by a former assistant principal and city councilor.

stories.headline: U.S. to pay $1,000 for self-deportation
stories.summary: The Trump administration plans to pay up to $1,000 to immigrants who illegally entered the U.S. and voluntarily return to their home countries, aiming to reduce illegal immigration. This new policy involves using an app called CBP Home to facilitate the process. The Department of Homeland Security has already paid for plane tickets for some migrants, marking a shift towards incentivizing self-deportation.

stories.headline: 100% tariff threatened on foreign-made films
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is pushing a plan to impose a 100% tariff on films made outside the U.S. to protect the domestic movie industry and boost production in America. The proposal targets foreign films and streaming content entering the U.S., causing concern among the entertainment industry about potential impacts on international cooperation and market dynamics.

stories.headline: Robots delivering solar innovation
stories.summary: Energy companies in Texas are exploring automation to build large-scale solar farms faster and safer. Rosendin Electric, the largest employee-owned electrical contractor in the U.S., is using revolutionary robotic solutions, including AI-enabled robots and pile-driving robots, to deploy solar panels more efficiently amid labor shortages and challenges in construction.

stories.headline: Water quality, or new limits?
stories.summary: A bill in the Texas Legislature proposes monitoring wastewater for substances including the abortion drug mifepristone, stirring debate over environmental monitoring versus intimidation. Advocates for abortion rights see the bill as an attempt to attack abortion access, while supporters say the focus is on environmental safety. The bill is part of broader legislation led by Sen. Bryan Hughes addressing wastewater issues.

stories.headline: How unqualified graduates of truck-driving school hit Northwest roads in alleged bribery scheme
stories.summary: An investigation revealed that graduates from Skyline CDL School, operating in Washington and Oregon, obtained commercial driver's licenses through a bribery scheme. Scores of unqualified drivers passed their tests without proper evaluations, with some never tested at all. Washington regulators found fraudulent intstructors and document falsifications enabling unsafe drivers on Northwest roads, raising concerns about road safety and regulatory oversight.

stories.headline: Trump budget would slash housing funds in Washington
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is proposing a budget that includes a 23% cut to domestic programs, targeting affordable housing and block grants. The plan seeks to slash funds for affordable housing, impose cuts to HUD and Health and Human Services, affecting services like job training and public infrastructure support. The proposed budget, if passed, would impact rental assistance and programs aiding low-income residents in Washington state.

stories.headline: Seattle hospital program erases disparity in unnecessary C-sections
stories.summary: Providence Swedish First Hill's JUST Birth program promotes culturally affirming care and has been successful in reducing the disparity in unnecessary C-sections among Black and Indigenous families in King County. The program focuses on offering culturally mindful support, education, and advocates for Black and Indigenous patients, resulting in better birth outcomes and satisfaction for mothers like Rachia Moore and LaShaye Stanton-Phillips.

stories.headline: Israel OKs plans to seize Gaza and expand operations
stories.summary: Israel approved plans to seize the Gaza Strip and stay in the Palestinian territory for an unspecified amount of time, following a vote by Israeli Cabinet ministers. The operations plan aims to enforce displacement and further military actions after recent conflicts. The situation remains tense with potential for escalation, amid discussions on ceasefire negotiations and military strategies involving Hamas and other groups.

stories.headline: New Rite Aid bankruptcy could kill Bartell Drugs
stories.summary: Rite Aid is planning to sell off all its assets, including Seattle-based Bartell Drugs, as part of bankruptcy protection measures to address debt and shutter stores. The national drugstore chain's current bankruptcy, filed in September 2024, jeopardizes the future of nearly 100 Bartell stores and about 40 in Alaska. The company aims to continue operating stores and support pharmacy services during the sale process.

stories.headline: Bessent says Trump's economy is one big power play, not just the pieces
stories.summary: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent characterized President Trump's economic agenda as a comprehensive strategy focused on deregulation, trade, and tax policies aimed at boosting long-term American investment. He emphasized an interconnected approach encompassing economic growth, health, and global challenges, pointing out that while markets face short-term concerns, the administration aims to position the U.S. advantageously for future success.

stories.headline: FDA told to rethink abortion pill rules
stories.summary: Pressure is mounting on the Food and Drug Administration to reconsider safeguards on abortion pill usage following a major study that found a much higher incidence of serious health effects than previously acknowledged. Pro-life advocates and researchers call for a fresh look at the agency's policies to ensure safety, highlighting new data showing significant adverse events in women prescribed mifepristone.

stories.headline: Catholics see chance to reverse wokeness
stories.summary: Many conservative U.S. Catholics hope the upcoming papal conclave will elect a successor to Pope Francis who is more traditional and focused on doctrine, potentially reversing the current church direction perceived as wokeness. The conclave is seen as an opportunity to restore clarity and roots to the church, with expectations that the new pope will hold less ambiguity on social justice and inclusion issues.

stories.headline: ICE nabs illegal after Fairfax DA drops case
stories.summary: ICE arrested an illegal immigrant accused of trying to kidnap and rape a 4-year-old Virginia girl after the Fairfax County Commonwealth's Attorney's Office dropped the charges. The immigrant, a Honduran, was charged initially in June 2023 for breaking into a home and attempting the assault. The case's dismissal follows a policy change that led to many dismissed cases involving unauthorized migrants.

stories.headline: Feds offer $1,000 to immigrants who self-deport
stories.summary: The Department of Homeland Security announced a $1,000 reward for illegal immigrants who self-deport from the U.S. This 'travel assistance' program incentivizes leaving independently rather than waiting for formal deportation. Homeland Security emphasized cost-effectiveness and the goal of encouraging voluntary departures, with payments made after immigrants confirm they have left the country.

stories.headline: 2027 NFL draft heads to National Mall
stories.summary: The 2027 NFL draft will be held for the first time on the National Mall in Washington, D.C., marking a return to the capital. President Trump announced the decision, highlighting the event as a celebration of the nation's cherished cultural institutions and a boost to business and tourism. The draft will attract attention and economic activity, with plans for three-day events and games involving NFL teams.

stories.headline: Trump offers $1,000 to immigrants who self-deport
stories.summary: The Trump administration has announced a plan to offer immigrants living illegally in the U.S. a $1,000 payment to self-deport via a new app called CBP Home. The initiative aims to encourage voluntary departure but has faced criticism for potential long-term consequences. The app facilitates appointment bookings for processing deportations, and those who self-deport may also qualify for federal funds to help with travel expenses.

stories.headline: Bill would repay state $800M for border costs
stories.summary: Texas leaders seek to recover nearly $800 million in reimbursement from the federal government for border security expenses. This amount is part of a larger $11 billion request tied to the crackdown on border activities during the Biden administration. The funds were included in legislation building a massive spending bill, with Texas being a significant contributor to this bipartisan federal effort.

stories.headline: Chronicle's Editorial Board wins Pulitzer
stories.summary: The Houston Chronicle's editorial department has won the Pulitzer Prize for Editorial Writing for the second time in four years. The awarded series highlighted the failures of railroads and state officials in protecting Houston residents from dangers caused by stopped and slow-moving trains. The editorial board aims to foster community awareness and encourage changes to prevent these issues.

stories.headline: Awaiting help ahead of hurricane season
stories.summary: The Carl Walker Jr. Multi-Service Center in Houston's Fifth Ward faces challenges due to uncertainty with federal funding, limiting its ability to serve as a disaster refuge. Despite having supplies and survival meals, the center cannot function fully because it lacks generators and a solar power system. Efforts are underway to secure grants for solar panels to improve resilience in future disasters.

stories.headline: Plan to shut FEMA creates uncertainty
stories.summary: There is growing concern over a plan proposed by Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem that would eliminate FEMA, forcing states to manage disaster response and recovery on their own. FEMA currently coordinates federal aid and recovery assistance to states during disasters. The plan raises questions about how prepared states are to handle emergencies without federal support, especially in the face of increasing severe disasters linked to climate change. The proposal has been characterized as a misinformation campaign pooling federal resources away from states to save money.

stories.headline: Administration wants to cut LGBTQ+ line for 988 callers
stories.summary: The Trump administration plans to cut funding for a specialized crisis line dedicated to LGBTQ+ youths on the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline, according to a leaked budget proposal. Calls from LGBTQ+ youths and other high-risk groups may require culturally sensitive responses that this specialized line offers. Advocates say cutting the funding could negatively impact suicide prevention efforts for LGBTQ+ youth and those facing complex related issues such as discrimination and family rejection.

stories.headline: Ex-prosecutor says Dugan 'perp walk' was political act
stories.summary: Judge Hannah Dugan arrived at the Milwaukee County Courthouse expecting a normal day. However, she was cuffed, shackled, and subjected to a public 'perp walk,' which several federal agents conducted. Dugan was frisked and handcuffed before being driven to a federal courthouse. This incident is being viewed as a political act rather than a routine procedure.

stories.headline: Trump admin: Pay undocumented immigrants to leave
stories.summary: The Trump administration announced a plan to pay $1,000 to undocumented immigrants willing to return to their home countries voluntarily. This self-deportation initiative aims to use financial travel assistance and a hotline to encourage voluntary departure as an alternative to detention and removal. The administration is also seeking a massive increase in resources for Immigration and Customs Enforcement to remove individuals illegally in the country.

stories.headline: Board set to announce finalists
stories.summary: Harteselle City Schools is progressing in its search for a new superintendent. A pool of 16 applicants was narrowed to eight who met the minimum qualifications, all deemed highly qualified. A board meeting is scheduled to announce the names of the finalists and initiate public review as part of the selection process.

stories.headline: Bachuss to serve out term
stories.summary: Decatur school board member Doug Bachuss announced he will take a new job in Birmingham but will serve out his term as District 3 school board member before moving next May. He has been actively involved in local education and is known for never missing a meeting as long as he was elected. He plans to address real estate related issues in his new role while continuing his work in education until his term ends.

stories.headline: Tennis facility nears completion
stories.summary: The new indoor tennis facility at Point Mallard Park is nearing completion with a sprinkler system being installed. The city expects to open the facility soon, enhancing local sports and recreation opportunities in Decatur.

stories.headline: Jubilee returns for 48th year
stories.summary: The Alabama Jubilee Hot-Air Balloon Classic, the longest running hot air balloon festival in the nation, returns to Decatur on Memorial Day weekend for its 48th year. More than 30,000 guests and around 60 pilots from across the country are expected to attend at Point Mallard Park. Organizers highlight the festival's broad appeal and its capacity to attract diverse travelers.

stories.headline: Maine schools, MPA don’t do enough on hazing
stories.summary: Concerns have been raised about recent hazing incidents involving high school sports teams in Maine, particularly the Mt. Ararat boys hockey and Westhill High School boys lacrosse teams. Investigations revealed patterns of abusive and humiliating behavior by teenagers. Appeals to return the hockey team to the ice for the 2025-26 season are expected to be denied due to the seriousness of the behavior.

stories.headline: Medical pot industry rallies against mold testing, plant tracking bills
stories.summary: Maine's medical cannabis market is opposing two bills that require more stringent testing for mold, yeast, chemicals, heavy metals, and plant tracking. Industry representatives expressed concerns that the legislation would impose burdens on their operations. The bills aim to improve regulation but are seen by some as an uphill battle for the cannabis industry.

stories.headline: Maine student loan borrowers worry about their debt as past-due collections resume
stories.summary: Nearly 190,000 Mainers hold a collective $6.5 billion in student loan debt that the federal government is now seeking to collect after years of leniency following COVID-era policies. Many borrowers face hardships as repayment plans and forgiveness options remain confusing, while collections resumed in April. About 186,700 people owe much of this debt, and there is concern about the financial impact on these individuals.

stories.headline: Downpours threaten flooding across Maine
stories.summary: An unusual weather pattern causing sudden downpours and continuous rain is expected to lead to flooding in parts of Maine through Wednesday. The greatest threat is in York County and southwestern Maine, where rivers like the Ogunquit have already received 2-3 inches of rainfall over the weekend.

stories.headline: Former Gov. LePage announces run for Congress in 2nd district
stories.summary: Former Gov. Paul LePage announced he is running to represent Maine's 2nd Congressional District in Congress. LePage, who served as governor from 2011 to 2019 and unsuccessfully ran for a third term, plans to contest the 2026 election and aims to reclaim the seat currently held by Democratic Rep. Jared Golden. He emphasized the need for more straight talk and all-world business experience in Washington, citing interest in issues like inflation and support for Donald Trump.

stories.headline: Among Catholics, 'Pope Trump' online gag doesn't go over well
stories.summary: The upcoming conclave to elect Pope Francis' successor sparked reactions when a developer associated with former President Donald Trump posted a gag about 'Pope Trump' online. The joke was met with disapproval among devout Catholics and church officials, including Detroit Catholic School Heritage Project representatives and New York Cardinal Timothy Dolan, who found the gag inappropriate given the solemnity of the papal election.

stories.headline: Charges in U-M protests dropped
stories.summary: Michigan Attorney General Dana Nessel dropped all charges against seven pro-Palestinian protesters arrested last year during University of Michigan protests. The charges included misdemeanor trespassing and felony charges of resisting and obstructing police. The defendants, who pleaded not guilty, appeared relieved and happy as the charges were dropped, which was described as a positive outcome for the protesters involved.

stories.headline: UAW: INVEST IN WORKERS
stories.summary: UAW members rallied on May 5 at Local 372 near the Stellantis Trenton Engine complex to push the automaker to increase the utilization of its auto plant capacity. A white paper by the union emphasized that automakers could use existing facilities to manufacture more cars in the U.S., advocating for greater investment in workers to support production expansion.

stories.headline: Ford expects a $1.5 billion tariff hit
stories.summary: Ford Motor Co. reported that first-quarter earnings are lower than a year ago due to impacts from tariffs and plant shutdowns. Despite some sales momentum, the company expects tariffs to reduce full-year adjusted EBIT by about $1.5 billion, which is included in its May 5 report. Ford warned of ongoing tariff-related uncertainties and has adjusted its financial guidance accordingly.

stories.headline: Missouri eminent domain laws put on trial
stories.summary: A lawsuit challenges Brentwood's use of blight power for property redevelopment along Manchester Road, claiming improper utilization. The suit argues that the city's use of blighted classification and eminent domain is not justified. Brentwood counters that conditions in the area have improved with a $120 food mitigation project and road and sidewalk improvements. Critics argue that the legal pressure creates a city-use of eminent domain without proper sense.

stories.headline: Rollback derails a housing complaint
stories.summary: A local transgender man, Tazz Webster, alleges discrimination based on gender identity after being called the wrong name and ridiculed by the government-subsidized building's manager. Webster filed a complaint with the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity office, which is investigating housing discrimination and enforcing fair access laws. The timing of the closure of a related investigation is noted as coincidental.

stories.headline: Officers honored at 39th Annual Memorial Breakfast
stories.summary: A ceremony was held at Union Station in St. Louis to honor the 167 police officers who have died in the line of duty from 1863 to 2024. The event included blowing out a candle in remembrance during the 39th Memorial Breakfast.

stories.headline: Trump to pay immigrants to leave
stories.summary: The Biden administration announces a plan to pay $1,000 to immigrants who are in the United States illegally and who volunteer to return to their home country. The Department of Homeland Security states that it will also cover travel assistance and that those who self-deport using an app will avoid detention and removal by immigration enforcement, promoting a safer and cost-effective exit strategy.

stories.headline: Hegseth orders 20% cut to military brass
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has directed a 20% reduction in the number of active duty four-star general officers as part of efforts to streamline leadership under the Trump administration. The cuts aim to remove redundant positions and decrease excessive military bureaucracy, potentially impacting around 800 general officers and flag officers across the military. The move is part of a broader push to improve military efficiency.

stories.headline: Will the state’s GOP remain united for Trump?
stories.summary: Maryland's elected Republicans are divided over their support for President Donald Trump ahead of the 2026 midterm elections. Some remain loyal while others express reservations, reflecting internal party challenges. Senate Minority Whip Justin Ready represents moderate Republicans advocating for consolidated leadership and policy strategy amidst these divisions.

stories.headline: Police identify Baltimore boy, 6, killed by gunshot
stories.summary: Baltimore police have identified a 6-year-old boy named Micah Comegys, who was killed by a gunshot wound last weekend. The incident occurred in Southwest Baltimore, and police found the boy wounded in a home on Vine Street. Authorities have not determined whether the shooting was self-inflicted or caused by another person. The community mourns the loss and the investigation is ongoing.

stories.headline: Ravens cut Tucker amid misconduct investigation
stories.summary: The Baltimore Ravens released longtime kicker Justin Tucker following an ongoing NFL investigation into allegations of inappropriate sexual behavior at several Baltimore-area spas and wellness centers. The team described the decision as a 'football decision' amidst accusations made by multiple massage therapists. Tucker has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing, and the NFL's investigation continues.

stories.headline: Port’s auto importers navigate Trump’s tariffs
stories.summary: Mitsubishi Motors and other foreign car makers are dealing with the impact of Trump's administration tariffs that now have cars headed to customers in limbo. Some are keeping vehicles in Japan or port facilities and weighing options such as releasing them or absorbing tariff costs. The situation is fluid as the Trump administration considers changes to the tariff policy impacting imports from Japan and other countries.

stories.headline: Trump’s call to reopen Alcatraz spurs backlash
stories.summary: Former President Donald Trump called for reopening Alcatraz prison as a symbolic tough-on-crime measure. The idea faced criticism given Alcatraz’s history as a harsh federal prison. Officials noted the high costs and extensive renovations needed, and the federal Bureau of Prisons and US Attorney’s office indicated no current plans to implement such an idea. The proposal draws attention to Trump’s law and order agenda and its controversial approach toward criminals and justice.

stories.headline: Republicans, Democrats clash over state’s sex offender laws
stories.summary: The latest political clash between Republicans and Democrats centers on protecting minors from sexual predators. Republicans accuse Democrats of protecting offenders by opposing tougher laws, while Democrats claim Republicans use cynical political tactics to distract from promises of lower costs for Americans and better protection laws. The debate is intensifying as the state legislature considers stronger protections for minors from sexual predators.

stories.headline: Grisly recounting of Davis stabbing spree opens trial
stories.summary: The trial began for Carlos Reales Dominguez, accused of a stabbing spree in Davis five months ago that paralyzed a victim. Dominguez has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity. The case involves allegations of multiple stabbings and a death penalty threat. Judge Samuel McAdam warned jurors to focus on the defendant's state of mind when determining guilt, as the trial moves through phases to establish the facts and extent of the attacks.

stories.headline: Trump says ‘I don’t know’ when asked about due process
stories.summary: President Donald Trump was uncertain when asked in an interview if every person on American soil was entitled to due process. He repeatedly responded with "I don't know," acknowledging he is not a lawyer, and expressed doubts about the applicability of the Fifth Amendment in this context. The exchange was prompted by a question about Secretary of State Marco Rubio's statement on citizenship rights and immigration enforcement, highlighting Trump's ambiguous stance on the issue.

stories.headline: A stunning collapse — Boston Celtics guards Jaylen Brown and Jrue Holiday walked off the court after falling 108-105 to the New York Knicks in overtime in Game One of the NBA Eastern Conference semifinal at the TD Garden.
stories.summary: In a dramatic finish, the Boston Celtics lost Game One of the NBA Eastern Conference semifinal to the New York Knicks in overtime, falling 108-105. Guards Jaylen Brown and Jrue Holiday were seen walking off the court after the close and hard-fought game, signaling challenges ahead for the Celtics in the playoff series.

stories.headline: How a trip to a jungle helped Mazzulla be coach Celtics needed
stories.summary: Boston Celtics head coach Joe Mazzulla used a transformative experience in a jungle setting to develop the mindset and coaching skills needed to lead the team effectively. Despite never meeting the famed chess prodigy Josh Waitzkin in person, Mazzulla used lessons from Waitzkin's story as part of his preparation for the 2023 Eastern Conference finals, enabling him to handle high-pressure situations.

stories.headline: US targets Harvard grants
stories.summary: The Trump administration announced that Harvard University will no longer be eligible for new research grants until it complies with demands related to transparency and other issues. Additionally, city councilor Tania Fernandes Anderson pled guilty to fraud and theft charges involving a $7,000 kickback, and Boston joined a lawsuit seeking $3.6 billion in federal grants for homelessness and improved transit. Symbotic is cutting 400 jobs amid operational changes.

stories.headline: Detained Tufts student flags state of facility
stories.summary: A Tufts University doctoral candidate, Rümeysa Öztürk, has described overcrowded and inadequate conditions at an immigration detention facility in rural Louisiana. Öztürk, who is currently detained, reported 45-minute asthma attacks and other health issues, highlighting ongoing concerns with treatment and facility management for immigrants in detention centers.

stories.headline: Bearing the cost of child-bearing
stories.summary: As the White House encourages women to have more children, many face economic hardships that make expanding their families difficult. The Trump administration's fertility incentives have fallen short for women like Colleen Nguyen, who struggles with the high cost of parenting a second child including healthcare and housing expenses. Economic anxiety has prevented many from fulfilling their desire for more children.

stories.headline: Israel set to launch ‘forceful’ Gaza plan
stories.summary: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced a new military plan approved by his cabinet to forcibly enter Gaza amid ongoing conflict. The strategy involves seizing territory and relocating Palestinians south, with intensified military efforts and a call for Hamas to surrender amid deteriorating conditions. The escalation follows months of blockade and bombing in the region.

stories.headline: House speaker’s earmark raises eyebrows
stories.summary: House Speaker Ron Mariano used surplus from a new tax on high earners to fund a $25 million parking garage in the South Shore city, raising questions about the use of the $1.3 billion spending bill. The earmark drew criticism for its perceived mismatch with the original intent of the tax surcharge, which was designed to support education and public transportation infrastructure.

stories.headline: Native tribes argue over land protection
stories.summary: Several Native American tribes, including Gabrielino Band of Mission Indians and Kizh Nation, are disputing over a newly proposed bill that could limit their role in land development disputes in the Los Angeles Basin. Concerned about losing sovereignty and environmental review input, tribes are voicing opposition against Assembly Bill 52, which they say erodes their non-federally recognized status and rights.

stories.headline: Trump’s California ratings stay low
stories.summary: Polls show that 68% of registered voters in California disapprove of President Trump's job performance. Despite campaigning in California, Trump remains deeply unpopular, with many voters doubting his leadership effectiveness and expressing concerns about his policies, especially regarding deportations. The poll underscores ongoing challenges for Trump in gaining support in the state.

stories.headline: Movie industry reacts to tariffs twist
stories.summary: Hollywood executives are responding to President Trump's proposal of imposing a 100% tariff on movies produced in foreign countries, which could disrupt the industry given many productions rely on foreign-made assets. Studios show concern over the potential impact on film projects and international cooperation, with tariffs seen as a threat to the industry's economic dynamics.

stories.headline: Israel plans to take over Gaza, relocate Palestinians to south
stories.summary: Israel approved a plan to expand operations in Gaza, which would involve seizing the Gaza Strip and relocating Palestinians to the southern part of Gaza. This move aims to pressure Hamas for a deal but risks worsening the humanitarian crisis amid a blockade and fuel shortages. The plan includes a significant military effort with notable humanitarian concerns and opposition internationally.

stories.headline: Migrants offered $1,000 to leave the U.S.
stories.summary: The Trump administration announced a plan offering unauthorized immigrants $1,000 if they voluntarily return to their home countries as part of ramping up deportations. The Department of Homeland Security views this as a historic opportunity to encourage self-deportation and impose financial incentives for immigrants to leave the U.S., while critics argue it may trivialize the complex issue of immigration.

stories.headline: 2 Republicans are first to enter governor's race
stories.summary: Nancy Dahlstrom and Click Bishop have officially filed to run for governor in Alaska's 2026 election. Both are experienced politicians with backgrounds in state government. Observers expect a crowded field of candidates to vie for the position to succeed current Governor Mike Dunleavy, who is not seeking a third term. The election is attracting considerable attention from political analysts and voters alike.

stories.headline: Alaska-based author, artist wins Pulitzer Prize for memoir ‘Feeding Ghosts’
stories.summary: Alaska author Tessa Hulls won the 2025 Pulitzer Prize for Memoir or Autobiography for her graphic memoir 'Feeding Ghosts.' Hulls spent ten years working on the project, which reflects on her family's history and personal experiences. The award recognizes her significant contribution to literature and memoir writing.

stories.headline: Immigrants to be offered $1,000 to leave if they are in the US illegally
stories.summary: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security announced a plan that would pay $1,000 to undocumented immigrants who voluntarily depart the United States and return to their home countries. This initiative is part of a broader immigration enforcement strategy under the Trump administration, intended to reduce illegal immigration by providing financial assistance and flight tickets for some immigrants to leave the country voluntarily.

stories.headline: Group rallies to preserve hidden orchard in the heart of city's commercial sprawl
stories.summary: A group called Friends of Boyer's Orchard is campaigning to protect a secret orchard in South Anchorage threatened by commercial development. The orchard blooms with various fruits and is valued by the community for its natural beauty and heritage. Volunteers and organizers are concerned the property could be lost to urban sprawl and have launched efforts to raise awareness and preserve it.

stories.headline: Daily News’ Stone, a trailblazer, honored by Pulitzer Prize Board
stories.summary: Chuck Stone, a pioneering former Daily News columnist, was posthumously honored with a special citation from the Pulitzer Prize Board for his groundbreaking work covering the Civil Rights Movement. Stone was recognized for his role at the Daily News, his contributions as a cofounder of the National Association of Black Journalists, and his lasting influence on journalism. This tribute honors a career spanning over half a century.

stories.headline: Haverford president prepares to testify on antisemitism
stories.summary: Haverford College President Wendell Raymond issued an apology regarding antisemitism incidents on campus and announced plans to testify before Congress. The college has faced scrutiny over antisemitic complaints including a lawsuit, a suspended student, and protests. Raymond's statement and forthcoming testimony reflect efforts to address campus tensions and ensure safety and inclusivity for all students.

stories.headline: Camden diocese won't oppose probe
stories.summary: The new bishop of Camden announced that the diocese will no longer oppose a statewide investigation into sex abuse by clergy. This marks a reversal after past resistance and aims to allow victims' voices to be heard. Bishop Joseph A. Williams emphasized the importance of supporting abuse survivors and ending efforts to block the probe, highlighting a shift in the diocese’s approach to accountability and justice.

stories.headline: Israel approves plan to seize Gaza, displace Palestinians, officials say
stories.summary: Israel has approved a plan to seize the Gaza Strip and displace Palestinians, potentially for an unspecified duration. This move, likely to expand Israeli military operations and provoke national opposition, involves mobilizing thousands of reservists and could worsen humanitarian crises. The plan’s full details are not disclosed, with timing and specifics still uncertain, but it has drawn concern over the forced displacement of Palestinians and the political ramifications.

stories.headline: Hill found guilty in 2019 police shootings
stories.summary: Maurice Hill, who shot six Philadelphia police officers during a 2019 standoff in Tioga, was found guilty of three counts of attempted murder and related charges. The court highlighted his actions as a significant attack on police with evidence including AR-15 rounds. Hill's defense argued he acted in self-defense during a tense situation, but jurors rejected this claim and convicted him.

stories.headline: Family members of slain woman speak of loss
stories.summary: In the aftermath of Brandon Marto's death, family members of Christina Spicuzza, who was slain, share their grief and memories. Those close to the victim describe the difficulty in coping with the tragedy and their desire to seek justice. The ongoing investigation and court hearings continue to draw attention to the case.

stories.headline: Pa. House panel advances marijuana bill
stories.summary: A Pennsylvania House committee approved a bill to legalize recreational marijuana in the state after its introduction and debate. The bill outlines a projected $500 million in revenue and seeks to establish rules for the use and sale of cannabis. Although it faces some opposition, the bill is set to be voted on by the full House later in the week.

stories.headline: POWERLESS FEELING
stories.summary: Recovery from a recent severe storm is ongoing, with around 16,000 Duquesne Light customers still without electricity as of Monday. Efforts include repairs by Midwest Powerline workers amidst difficult weather conditions. Affected residents continue to face challenges, with some dealing with health issues and hardships caused by the prolonged outage.

stories.headline: $1,000 OFFERED TO THOSE WHO LEAVE
stories.summary: The Trump administration announced a plan to pay $1,000 to immigrants who voluntarily leave the United States. The Department of Homeland Security aims to encourage self-deportation by offering financial travel assistance and a stipend through an app called CBP Home. This initiative is part of the administration's broader immigration enforcement strategy.

stories.headline: TSA changes security at PIT
stories.summary: The Pittsburgh International Airport has implemented a new security checkpoint system as part of TSA's upgraded policy. The changes include the use of alternate checkpoints such as the PreCheck expedited screening program. Officials reported that long security lines moved quickly on the first day of the new system.

stories.headline: 76 Years of Longing for a Child Taken From Her
stories.summary: An Irish woman named Chrissie Tully has waited 76 years for her son's return after he was taken from her in infancy. Despite decades-long search and emotional hardship, she remains hopeful as she continues to advocate for awareness about adoption and family separation issues. The story highlights the personal impacts of historical adoption practices and resonates with themes of maternal love and resilience.

stories.headline: Reigning Supreme at the Met Gala
stories.summary: Singer Diana Ross was the star of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's latest extravaganza, the Met Gala, which raised $31 million for the Costume Institute. The high-profile event featured celebrities and influencers in glamorous attire, highlighting the intersection of fashion, art, and philanthropy. Coverage of the event captivated popular culture audiences and continues to be a major highlight of the social calendar.

stories.headline: 'Made in America' Becomes Trade War Casualty
stories.summary: European countries, including Sweden and France, see their goods losing market access in the U.S. due to imposed reciprocal tariffs linked to the 'Made in America' campaign by the Trump administration. American tariffs on European products like Lay’s potato chips and McDonald's fries trigger retaliatory tariffs from Europe, affecting trade relations. This trade war casualty reflects ongoing tension between the U.S. and European Union in global commerce and policy enforcement.

stories.headline: 'INTENSIVE' PUSH PLANNED IN GAZA
stories.summary: The Palestinian population in Gaza faces intensified military escalation as Israel continues blockade and bombardment. Prime Minister Netanyahu and military officials announce efforts to end hostilities and bring hostages home, amid international calls for ceasefire talks. The conflict has resulted in significant humanitarian deprivation and casualties, with Israel accusing Hamas of causing the stalemate. The situation remains volatile with uncertain prospects for peace as violence continues.

stories.headline: V.A. Staff, Crammed in Offices, Says Patient Privacy Is Suffering
stories.summary: The Veterans Affairs hospital in Boston and other locations report overcrowded offices causing compromised patient privacy and care. Staffers and patients alike express concern over makeshift office setups and cramped conditions. The problem impacts telehealth and in-person visits, with staff and patient confidentiality risks mounting. This issue highlights ongoing resource and logistical challenges post-pandemic within the V.A. system, especially in mental health and nursing care units.

stories.headline: DEMOCRATS BLAST CRYPTO DEALINGS OF TRUMP FAMILY
stories.summary: Senate Democrats demand investigations into cryptographic financial dealings involving the Trump family, highlighting national security concerns. The legislation aims to tighten crypto laws, responding to the Trump family's use of crypto trading for profit. Lawmakers worry about potential corruption and call for strict oversight. The proposed bill has bipartisan backing and aims to deliver transparency and regulation to the crypto industry, although some argue the move could politicize finance.

stories.headline: Vast Tent City For Deportees Fell Far Short
stories.summary: American military forces hastily set up tents at Guantánamo Bay to hold 497 migrants for deportation, far fewer than the 3,000 capacity originally planned. No migrants had died or surged during the operation, which lasted just three days. The Homeland Security and Defense Departments agreed to house dozens of ICE detainees at the base, used historically as a detention site for deportation purposes. Military operations were ongoing as officials continued to assess the situation.
